entrypoint-copy.body:
Find out what actions you should take before making child arrangements with the other parent.

Your plan will give you:

* clear advice that’s personal to you and your situation
* somewhere to record how you’re feeling
* a way of keeping track of what you’ve done

You’ll be asked a maximum of {wizardStepsLength} questions. The more questions you answer, the more detailed your plan will be.

All the information you enter will remain confidential.

route:action_plan.title: Get started
route:action_plan.heading: Make a plan for agreeing child arrangements

route:staying_safe.heading: Staying safe
route:staying_safe.lede: Thinking about your situation with your ##default:children##’s other parent:

error-header:heading: There were problems on the page

children_safety.label: Are you worried about the safety of your ##default:children##?

parent_safety.label: Is the other parent acting in a way that makes you worried about your safety?

children_flight.label: Do you think your ##default:children## could be taken out of the country without your permission?
children_flight.Xlabel: {children_number, plural, =1 {Is} other {Are}} your ##default:children## at risk of being taken out of the country?

children_number.label: How many children are you trying to make arrangements for?

child_age_1.label: How old is {children_number, plural, =1 {your child} other {child 1}}?

children_resident.label: {children_number, plural, =1 {Does your} other {Do the}} ##default:children## live with you most of the time?

children_access_disagreements.label: Are you having disagreements about access that mean your ##default:children## {children_number, plural, =1 {isn’t} other {aren’t}} seeing { children_resident, select, respondent {you} applicant {their other parent} other {either parent}} currently?

children_input.label: {children_number, plural, =1 {Does} other {Do}} your ##default:children## want to give their opinion on how often they see each parent?
children_input.Xlabel: Would you like your ##default:children## to have a say in any agreements you make?

children_additional_support.label: {children_number, plural, =1 {Does} other {Do}} your ##default:children## need support from someone impartial to cope with your separation?
children_additional_support.Xlabel: Would you like information about additional help and support to help your ##default:children## to cope with your separation?

arrangements_duration.label: How long have you been trying to make child arrangements?

relationship_status.label: How is the relationship between you and the other parent?

communications_about_arrangements.label: How easy is it to communicate with each other about child arrangements?

communication_methods.label: How do you communicate with each other?

official_involvement_required.label: Do you need help from an official organisation to get the other parent involved with making child arrangements?

childcare_disagreements.label: Do you disagree with your ##default:children##’s other parent over medical treatment, religious activities and/or schooling?

legal_rights.label: Do you already know your legal rights and responsibilities as a parent?

options_tried.label: What options have you already tried?
options_tried.sublabel: Tick anything that you have already tried to help agree your arrangements

options_tried_written_agreement.label: Made a written agreement with my ex-partner

options_tried_leader.label: Spoken to a religious or community leader

options_tried_other_value.label: What other method did you try?

language_support.label: Do you struggle to understand English and need a translator to help you make child arrangements?

action:children_safety.title: Contact social services
action:children_safety.body: As you’re concerned about your ##default:children##’s safety, you should contact social services run by your local authority.

action:parent_safety.title: Contact Refuge
action:parent_safety.body: As you’re concerned about your child’s safety, you should contact social services run by your local authority.

action:children_flight.title: Keep your ##default:children##’s passport safe and ask a court for help
action:children_flight.body:
If you think your ##default:children## may be abducted at any minute you can do things like keeping their passport and making sure you know where they are at all times.
If the other parent has ‘parental responsibility’, you will have to go to court to ask for a ‘prohibited steps order’ which would prevent them doing things like taking your ##default:children## abroad.

action:children_access_disagreements.title: Arrange a visit to a contact centre
action:children_access_disagreements.body: Visiting a child contact centre means {children_resident, select, applicant {the other parent can still see your ##default:children## while you continue trying to agree longer-lasting arrangements} other {you can see your ##default:children## while you continue trying to agree longer-lasting arrangements with the other parent}}. You may have to pay a small fee to do this.

action:children_input.title: Discuss any arrangements with your ##default:children##
action:children_input.body: Contributing to any arrangements or plans you make with their other parent can help older children settle into and deal with the situation. Sit down with them, listen to concerns around eg friendships, homework, and take their suggestions on board.

action:children_additional_support.title: Additional support for your ##default:children##
action:children_additional_support.body: Listening to other children in a similar position can be a great starting point if your ##default:children## {children_number, plural, =1 {is} other {are}} struggling with your separation and disagreements over their arrangements.

action:spip.title: Go to a Separated Parents Information Programme (SPIP)
action:spip.body:
As you’ve been unable to agree arrangements for a long time, a SPIP may help. It lasts about 4 hours and gives you ways to avoid conflict and focus on your ##default:children##, rather than their other parent.
Both of you need to go to SPIP but you go to different ones so you never meet. SPIPs are free in some areas.

action:mediation.title: Go to mediation
action:mediation.body: As you’re struggling to come to an agreement, mediation may be able to help you work out a solution you can both accept. You usually have to pay for mediation although legal aid may be available in a small number of cases.

action:lawyer_mediation.title: Go to a lawyer mediator who will make a decision for you
action:lawyer_mediation.body: As you’ve having trouble coming to an agreement, a new kind of mediation might help. You both go to sessions and the lawyer mediator will try to help you. If you still can’t decide by the end, the mediator will make a decision about child arrangements for you.

action:odr.title: Sort out your dispute online and not face-to-face
action:odr.body: As you’re not comfortable seeing eye-to-eye with the other parent, you may be able to work things out online. There are some new options for you to do this although neither are free.

action:counselling.title: Get into the right mindset to deal with your child’s other parent
action:counselling.body: Making agreements can be even more difficult if you’re still angry, upset or emotional about the other parent. To help you get into the right mindset to discuss and agree on child arrangements, you might consider talking to a counsellor.

action:parental_involvement.title: Get help to make sure the other parent gets involved in child arrangements
action:parental_involvement.body:
We’re introducing a service to help the other parent get more involved. Here’s how it works:

1. You give permission to contact the other parent
1. An adviser contacts the other parent
1. The adviser explains benefits of working together to agree out of court
1. The adviser explains what might happen if they don’t engage and then have to go to court

action:legal_disagreements.title: Get professional help to understand your legal position
action:legal_disagreements.body: It’s important to understand your legal position if your arguments are around these topics. There are a number of different options you can try.

action:legal_info.title: Find out what your legal rights and responsibilities are
action:legal_info.body: All parents have legal rights and responsibilities that include providing a home, protecting and looking after the child. These rights mean you should also be able to see your ##default:children## in most circumstances.

action:written_agreement.title: Make a written plan of your child arrangements
action:written_agreement.body: A parenting plan offers a good way to work out your arrangements with the other parent, address concerns and record what you’ve agreed. You can write your plan down on paper or do it online. You can make it very detailed or start small and add to it as you go and as your ##default:children## {children_number, plural, =1 {grows} other {grow}}.

action:language_support.title: Language support
action:language_support.body: As you’ve said that you struggle to understand English, you may need a translator to help you. These services may not be free.

link:family_lawyer.title: Find a local family lawyer (not free)

link:representing_oneself.title: Find out about going to court yourself

link:talking_with_children.title: How to talk with your children

link:mediation_with_decision.title: Find out more about mediation with a decision

link:amicable_app.title: Download and register with Amicable App

link:find_legal_aid_centre.title: Find a free legal advice centre
